<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 146, 244]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 913, 91]]<|/det|>
Many household smoke alarms contain a sample of the radioactive isotope americium-241 (Am).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
State how the composition of a nucleus of americium-241 differs from that of a nucleus of americium-242.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 252, 695, 271]]<|/det|>
An atom of a different element has a nucleon number of 241.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 284, 920, 317]]<|/det|>
State two differences between the composition of a nucleus of this atom and a nucleus of americium-241.

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 401, 915, 420]]<|/det|>
Americium-241 decays to an isotope of neptunium (Np) by alpha-particle (\(\alpha\)-particle) emission.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 181, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 431, 504, 450]]<|/det|>
Complete the equation for this decay.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 453, 752, 496]]<|/det|>
\[241 \xrightarrow{\text{Am}} \xrightarrow{\text{......}} 93 \xrightarrow{\text{Np}} + \xrightarrow{\text{......}} \alpha\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 486, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 516, 181, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 516, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
One reason for using an isotope that emits \(\alpha\)-particles in a smoke detector is that \(\alpha\)-particles are more strongly ionising than beta-particles (\(\beta\)-particles).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 742, 581]]<|/det|>
Explain why \(\alpha\)-particles are more strongly ionising than \(\beta\)-particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 648, 920, 667]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 680, 181, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 680, 798, 698]]<|/det|>
The isotope of neptunium produced by americium-241 is also radioactive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 711, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
The decay of this isotope of neptunium produces an isotope of protactinium which decays by \(\beta\)-emission. \(\beta\)-particles are more penetrating than \(\alpha\)-particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 756, 670, 774]]<|/det|>
The half-life of neptunium is longer than two million years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 920, 818]]<|/det|>
Using this information, explain the advantage of this long half-life for the use and safe disposal of a household smoke alarm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 887, 920, 906]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 916, 920, 933]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
The Milky Way is one of many billions of galaxies. Each galaxy contains many billions of stable stars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Stable stars transfer energy into space by emitting electromagnetic radiation from their surfaces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Describe what happens in the core of a stable star to release energy that is eventually transferred into space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 146, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
On the Earth, light from a distant galaxy is observed and analysed by astronomers. This information is used to determine the speed at which the galaxy is moving away from the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 181, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 381, 767, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 920, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 581, 144, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<label>(i)</label>
